entry.title: My First Co-Authored Publication
entry.content:
My first paper as a co-author, ‚ÄúSynergistic Effects of Entropy Tuning in Niobium-Based Oxide Anode for Fast-Charging Lithium-Ion Batteries‚Äù, has been published in Advanced Functional Materials. This work was led by my research mentor Yoojin at Georgia Tech.

While pursuing my own project on cathode materials, I contributed to this work by preparing some of the electrode samples for electrochemical characterization and assisting with the final proofreading of the manuscript.

I am truly excited about this achievement, and would like to thank Yoojin and all the co-authors for their great collaboration.

The full paper can be found under ‚ÄúPublications‚Äù tab.
entry.summary: My first paper as a co-author, ‚ÄúSynergistic Effects of Entropy Tuning in Niobium-Based Oxide Anode for Fast-Charging Lithium-Ion Batteries‚Äù, has been published in Advanced Functional Materials. This work was led by my research mentor Yoojin at Georgia Tech.

entry.title: Undergraduate Research Assistant at Prof. Nam-Soon Choi‚Äôs lab at KAIST

link.title: Undergraduate Research Assistant at Prof. Nam-Soon Choi‚Äôs lab at KAIST

entry.content: Returning to my home university, I started a new position as an undergraduate research assistant in Energy Materials Lab (PI: Prof. Nam-Soon Choi) at KAIST. I will focus on studying electrolyte additives suitable for Na-ion batteries under low-temperature condition. I‚Äôm excited to delve into this new system and look forward to making meaningful contributions.
entry.summary: Returning to my home university, I started a new position as an undergraduate research assistant in Energy Materials Lab (PI: Prof. Nam-Soon Choi) at KAIST. I will focus on studying electrolyte additives suitable for Na-ion batteries under low-temperature condition. I‚Äôm excited to delve into this new system and look forward to making meaningful contributions.

entry.title: Wrapping up my Georgia Tech Exchange Journey

link.title: Wrapping up my Georgia Tech Exchange Journey

entry.content:
I have successfully completed my exchange program at the Georgia Institute of Technology, where I had the opportunity to adapt to a new environment, pursue research, and connect with a diverse international community.

Since I had been considering pursuing a Ph.D. in the U.S., I wanted to experience what life at a U.S. university would be like and see how well I could adapt during the exchange. However, adjusting to a new environment wasn‚Äôt as easy as it seemed. The cultural differences with Korea were greater than I expected, and I often struggled to express myself naturally since I wasn‚Äôt used to speaking English on a daily basis. Nevertheless, I pushed myself beyond my comfort zone and embraced new experiences, while also being fortunate to meet many supportive friends along the way. Over time, I found myself adapting more smoothly than I had expected, and I started to appreciate dynamic atmosphere and diverse perspectives around me. This journey not only boosted my confidence in English but also convinced me that I can thrive both academically and personally in the United States.

During the exchange, I devoted much of my effort to the research. At Prof. Meilin Liu‚Äôs lab, I deepened my understanding of lithium-ion batteries and gained valuable research experience working on cathode materials. Presenting my work in lab meetings and poster sessions further improved my scientific communication skills and prepared me for future academic challenges.

Beyond research, I lived in international dormitories (I-Lead and I-House), where I built lasting friendships with students from around the world. These interactions broadened my cultural awareness and communication skills, making the exchange a truly transformative chapter of my life journey.

It‚Äôs a little bit bittersweet to say goodbye to Georgia Tech, but I also look forward to embarking on a new chapter back at KAIST!
entry.summary: I have successfully completed my exchange program at the Georgia Institute of Technology, where I had the opportunity to adapt to a new environment, pursue research, and connect with a diverse international community.

entry.title: Georgia Tech 19th UROP Spring Symposium
entry.content: I successfully presented my ongoing research at the 19th UROP Spring Symposium, held at the Exhibition Hall at Georgia Tech. Building on the lessons learned from my previous MRS poster session, I was able to deliver a more refined and effective presentation.
entry.summary: I successfully presented my ongoing research at the 19th UROP Spring Symposium, held at the Exhibition Hall at Georgia Tech. Building on the lessons learned from my previous MRS poster session, I was able to deliver a more refined and effective presentation.

entry.title: Georgia Tech 12th Annual MRS Poster Competition

link.title: Georgia Tech 12th Annual MRS Poster Competition

entry.content:
I gave a poster presentation at the 12th Annual MRS Poster Competition, organized by the MRS Chapter at Georgia Tech and held at the Marcus Nanotechnology Building.

As an undergraduate researcher, I presented my ongoing work on investigating the effect of surface treatment on Ni/Mn-based Co-free layered oxide cathode for Li-ion Batteries. You can find the poster in the ‚ÄúProjects‚Äù section of this website.

This was my very first poster presentation. The whole processes of desiging the poster, preparing a short pitch, and answering questions from the audience helped me further develop my scientific comuunication skills. It was truly a fantastic experience.

I‚Äôd like to give a special shout-out to my mentor Yoojin and my advisor Prof. Meilin Liu for their invaluable advice and support.
entry.summary: I gave a poster presentation at the 12th Annual MRS Poster Competition, organized by the MRS Chapter at Georgia Tech and held at the Marcus Nanotechnology Building.

entry.title: Exchange Semester at Georgia Institute of Technology

link.title: Exchange Semester at Georgia Institute of Technology

entry.content:
Right after getting discharged from my service duty, I‚Äôm starting new chapter of my academic journey at Georgia Institute of Technology. Go Jackets! üêù

At Georgia Tech, I will be joining Prof. Meilin Liu‚Äôs research group as an undergraduate researcher, focusing on studying electrode materials for Lithium-ion batteries. In addition, I will be taking relevant courseworks, such as Electrochemical Energy Storage and Conversion, to fulfill my degree requirements at KAIST.

I‚Äôm also honored to be a recipient of KOR-US High-Tech Industry Student Exchange Scholarship, as the part of the KOR-US STEM Educational Exchange Initiative. This scholarship provides financial support of 9,000 USD and opportunities to visit leading research facilities across the United States.
entry.summary: Right after getting discharged from my service duty, I‚Äôm starting new chapter of my academic journey at Georgia Institute of Technology. Go Jackets! üêù

entry.title: Excellent Social Service Personnel Award
entry.content:
I‚Äôm honored to be a receipient of ‚Äú10th Excellent Social Service Personnel Award‚Äù (Ï†ú10Ìöå ÏÇ¨ÌöåÎ≥µÎ¨¥ÎåÄÏÉÅ) from the Korea Military Manpower Administration.

Since November 2022, I have been serving as a Social Service Personnel at the Muan Social Welfare Center as an alternative to mandatory military service.

I was recommended by my supervisor for my diligent attitude during the service, as well as for my contributions to improving the center‚Äôs facilities and my strong client service skills.

This news was also featured in a local newspaper.
entry.summary: I‚Äôm honored to be a receipient of ‚Äú10th Excellent Social Service Personnel Award‚Äù (Ï†ú10Ìöå ÏÇ¨ÌöåÎ≥µÎ¨¥ÎåÄÏÉÅ) from the Korea Military Manpower Administration.

entry.title: Best Study Award at KPF Student Academic Conference

link.title: Best Study Award at KPF Student Academic Conference

entry.content:
I won third prize out of 26 teams in the Best Study Award at the KPF (KAIST Presidential Fellowhip) Student Academic Conference, organized by Global Leadership Center at KAIST.

I submitted the work from my URP (KAIST Undergraduate Research Program) project last year, ‚ÄúDeveloping an Electrolytic Zn-Mn Battery System and Identifying Key Operating Conditions.‚Äù The full report can be found in the ‚ÄúProjects‚Äù section of this website.

I‚Äôm grateful to my mentor Kyungjae and my advisor Prof. Hee-Tak Kim for their support.
entry.summary: I won third prize out of 26 teams in the Best Study Award at the KPF (KAIST Presidential Fellowhip) Student Academic Conference, organized by Global Leadership Center at KAIST.
